newsitem.title: FRANCE: French youths print bank notes on home computer.
newsitem.headline: French youths print bank notes on home computer.

text.p: French police said on Saturday they had broken up a youthful ring of counterfeiters, comprised of seven high school students printing 100-franc ($17) and 200-franc bank notes on a home computer.
"The 100-franc note was particularly successful," Gendarmerie Captain Michel Balland in Thann, eastern France, told Reuters.
After questioning the seven youths, whose names were not released, prosecutors placed two of them under a judge's supervision before releasing them.
Police said their counterfeiting had begun as a game.

The students, from well-off families and with clearly advanced computer skills, scanned bank notes into their computer's memory, touched them up and then printed out the result on a high-quality laser printer.

In all, they sold some 15 bank notes at 20 francs (about $3.50) each until suspicious local merchants brought the bills to the attention of police, who tracked down the youths and brought them in for questioning. ($ = 5.818 French Francs)
